p: Influenza virus infection is commonly followed by secondary bacterial infection, leading to increased morbidity and mortality, particularly among susceptible groups including the elderly and the immunocompromised [ 1, 2]. Bacterial species with the potential to cause infections in the respiratory tract, such as Haemophilus influenza, Staphylococcus aureus, and Streptococcus pneumonia, are often found in association with influenza virus infections and have also been isolated from the upper respiratory tract of healthy individuals [ 3, 4]. The emergence and spread of antibiotic resistance strains of these potential pathogens, such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and multidrug resistance Streptococcus pneumonia, impact treatment and are of global concern.
